content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Kristen Hansen: I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and I've lived here most of my life. My parents were both working-class people who didn't have a lot of education, just high school diplomas. My mom worked part-time at a local store, and my dad worked in manufacturing. We weren't wealthy, but we had a stable home life. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books than in sports or socializing. I remember my mom reading to me every night before bed, and that really shaped my love for learning. I went to public school, and while I wasn't the best student, I was determined. I got my bachelor's degree in social work, which I chose because I wanted to help people who were in tough situations, like the ones I saw growing up. Life hasn't been easy—my parents divorced when I was in my early twenties, and I had to step up and take care of my younger brother for a while. I got married once, but that didn't last. Now I'm focused on my job, which is full-time, and I'm trying to save up for a better future. I still go to church every Sunday, and I think that gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Kristen Hansen: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. I was about 18, just finishing up my senior year of high school, and I had a choice to make. I could either take a job at the local grocery store like my mom did, or I could apply for a scholarship to a community college. I was torn because I knew the job would give me immediate stability, but I also felt like I was being held back. My high school teacher, Mrs. Thompson, saw something in me and encouraged me to go for the scholarship. She even helped me write my application essay. I got the scholarship, and that was the start of my journey toward becoming a social worker. Looking back, I realize that moment was a crossroads—choosing education over immediate work set me on a path to help others, even though it wasn't easy. I had to work part-time while going to school, and there were times I felt like giving up. But I kept going, and I think that decision ultimately made me who I am today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Kristen Hansen: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it didn't feel like it at the time. I remember sitting at my kitchen table, staring at the scholarship application, and feeling like I was standing at the edge of something big. I didn't have a lot of confidence back then, but I knew I didn't want to end up like my parents—working the same dead-end jobs, never really getting ahead. I made a list of all the reasons why I should go for it, and I kept that list with me every day. It wasn't just about me; I wanted to show my younger brother that there was more out there. So I made the choice, and I stuck with it, even when things got tough. I think that's when I started to believe in myself a little more.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Kristen Hansen: Absolutely, and I think that's why I ended up in social work. I remember reaching out to a local nonprofit that helped students apply for scholarships and financial aid. Their counselor, Mr. Delgado, took the time to sit down with me and walk me through the process. He didn't just help me fill out the paperwork—he helped me see that I was capable of more than I thought. Without his support, I might have stayed in that dead-end job, just like my parents. It was a reminder that sometimes, even when you feel stuck, there are people and organizations out there who believe in you enough to help you take that first step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Kristen Hansen: I don't have a partner right now, and I don't have any children. My family is my mom, my dad, and my younger brother, Jake. My parents are both in their sixties now, and they live in the same neighborhood where I grew up. My mom still works part-time at the same store she did when I was a kid, and my dad retired a few years ago after his manufacturing job. He's been helping out with some odd jobs around the neighborhood to stay busy. My brother is in his late twenties now, and he's actually doing pretty well—he went to community college and got a degree in IT. He works remotely for a company in California, which is something I never thought would happen for someone from our background. I still keep in touch with him, and I'm really proud of him. My parents and I don't always see eye to eye politically, especially since I'm a strong Democrat and they're more conservative, but we still have a good relationship. I try to visit them as much as I can, even though my job keeps me busy. Family has always been important to me, even when things got tough.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. Talking about my life story reminded me of the struggles I faced growing up and the choices I made that shaped who I am today. It was meaningful to revisit that crossroads at 18, when I chose education over a stable job, and to acknowledge how much support I received from people like Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Delgado. It also made me think about my family—how proud I am of my brother for carving out his own path, and how, despite our differences, my parents have always been a part of my life. It's interesting how these topics all connect, showing how my past has influenced my present, and how I continue to seek purpose through my work and relationships.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Kristen Hansen: My immediate family is just my mom, dad, and Jake. We don't have any other close relatives living nearby, though my mom's side of the family is in Minnesota. I haven't been in touch with them much over the years, mostly because my parents didn't talk about them much when I was growing up. I know they're still there, but I don't feel like I really know them. I guess that's something I've never fully resolved—feeling like there's a part of my family history that's missing. I don't know if it's because of the way my parents raised me or just the way things worked out. I don't hold any resentment toward them, but I do wonder what my life would have been like if I had known them better. I think that's why I've always been so close to my brother—he's the only one who really knows me, and I know him. He's like my anchor, even though we're not always on the same page.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Kristen Hansen: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. She was also studying social work, and we bonded over our shared interest in helping others. We've been friends for almost 20 years now, and even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like, she's someone I can always count on. She's the one who encouraged me to stay in the field when things got tough, especially after my divorce. Then there's my coworker, Mark, who's been a great support at work. He's been with the agency longer than I have, and he's always willing to lend a hand or offer advice. I don't have a romantic partner right now, but I think it's more about timing than anything else. I've been focused on my job and my family, and I know when the right person comes along, I'll recognize them. For now, I'm content with the people I have in my life—the ones who have stood by me through thick and thin.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Kristen Hansen: I live in a neighborhood that's pretty typical for Des Moines—quiet, family-oriented, and full of people who've been here for generations. My apartment is in a small complex near the edge of the city, not too far from the downtown area. It's not the most upscale place, but it's safe, and the rent is manageable on my salary. I like that I can walk to the local library, which is a big part of my life. I spend a lot of time there, either reading or volunteering a few hours a week. The neighborhood has a strong sense of community, and I've gotten to know a few of my neighbors over the years. There's Mrs. Alvarez who lives down the hall—she's in her seventies and always brings me fresh bread from her little bakery. Then there's Mr. Patel, who's a retired teacher and loves to talk about books. I think living here has helped me stay grounded, even with everything else going on in my life. It's not much, but it feels like home.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Kristen Hansen: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not the kind of neighborhood where you have to lock your doors at night or worry about strangers lurking around. There's a real sense of watchfulness among the neighbors, even if it's just a nod or a wave when you pass by. I've never had any issues with crime, and the local police are pretty responsive if anything does come up. It's not just the safety that makes me feel secure—it's the familiarity, the rhythm of daily life here. I know the routines of the people around me, and they know mine. That kind of comfort is hard to find, especially in a city as big as Des Moines. I think that's why I've stayed here all these years, even though I've had opportunities to move somewhere else. This place feels like a part of me now, and I don't think I'd be the same person if I lived somewhere else.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Kristen Hansen: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of community and the quiet pace of life. It's a place where I can feel at peace, especially after a long day at work. The library is a big part of that peace for me—it's like my second home. But there are downs too. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stuck in a cycle, working hard but not really moving forward financially. My savings are minimal, and I know that if something were to happen, like a medical emergency or a job loss, I wouldn't be able to handle it easily. I've thought about moving somewhere with more opportunities, but I'm also afraid of leaving the only home I've ever known. There's comfort in the familiar, even if it's not perfect. I guess that's just part of life—knowing that no place is perfect, but finding the best you can in what you have.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood brought up a lot of mixed feelings. Talking about my parents and brother reminded me of how far we've all come, even if we don't always agree on everything. It's interesting how my brother managed to break the cycle we were in, and I feel proud of him for that. At the same time, I can't help but think about the parts of my family history that feel incomplete, like the relatives I never got to know. It's strange how much those missing pieces affect me, even if I don't resent them. Then there's my neighborhood—living here has been a comfort, but I also feel stuck in a way. I love the sense of community and the safety, but I know I could be doing more with my life if I had more opportunities. It's a balance between being content with what I have and wanting more, and I think that's something I'll have to keep working through.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Kristen Hansen: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though there are a few variations depending on my workload. I usually start my week on Monday with a quiet morning—coffee, a quick walk around the neighborhood, and then heading to work. My job is at a local social services agency, and I work full-time, so I'm in the office from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. I handle case management for clients who are dealing with housing insecurity, domestic issues, or just need someone to talk to. It's demanding, but I find it rewarding. On most days, I have meetings, paperwork, and sometimes home visits. I try to take lunch breaks at the same time each day, usually walking to the library and reading for a bit or just sitting in the quiet corner with a cup of tea. On Fridays, I like to go to the grocery store and pick up a few things for the weekend. I also try to go to church every Sunday, which is a big part of my routine. On the weekends, I might meet up with Sarah for coffee or go to the library to volunteer. I also like to spend time with my family, especially my brother, even if it's just a phone call. There are days when I feel like I'm just going through the motions, but I remind myself that I'm doing something that matters, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Kristen Hansen: I work full-time at a local social services agency, and I'm on the case management team. My hours are pretty standard—8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. The job can be overwhelming at times, especially when I'm juggling multiple cases, but I find a lot of meaning in it. I get to work with people who are going through really tough situations, and it reminds me why I chose this path in the first place. I think my background growing up in a working-class family gives me a unique perspective. I can relate to the clients who are struggling to make ends meet or dealing with personal issues they don't know how to talk about. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel like I'm not making a difference, or when I'm stretched too thin. But I also have moments where I see someone get back on their feet, or find a little stability, and that's when I remember why I'm here. I've been at the agency for about five years now, and I've learned a lot, both professionally and personally. It's not the highest-paying job, but it's one that aligns with my values, and I can live with that.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Kristen Hansen: Outside of work and family, I have a few other routines that keep me grounded. Every evening after work, I like to take a walk around the neighborhood, especially when the weather is nice. It helps me clear my mind and reflect on the day. I also try to set aside some time each night for reading—usually a novel or something related to my work, like a book on social policy or psychology. It's a small way to continue learning, even when I'm not in school anymore. I also have a habit of journaling, though I don't do it every day. When I do, it's usually after a particularly tough case or when I'm feeling overwhelmed. Writing things down helps me process my emotions and reminds me that I'm not alone in what I'm going through. I think these little rituals are important—they give me a sense of control in a life that can sometimes feel out of my hands.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Kristen Hansen: One recent change to my routine has been starting to take online courses in my spare time. I enrolled in a few classes through a community college, mostly in social policy and mental health advocacy. It's something I've been wanting to do for a while, but I always put it off because of work and family. Now that my brother is doing well and my parents are stable, I feel like I can focus a little more on myself. It's been challenging, balancing work, study, and my other responsibilities, but I'm enjoying the process. I've always believed that education is a way to keep growing, even if you're not in school full-time. It's also been a way to stay connected to my roots—many of my classmates are people I grew up with, or at least people from similar backgrounds. It's interesting to see how we're all still figuring things out, even as adults. I think it's a reminder that no one ever really stops learning, and that's something I want to hold onto.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Kristen Hansen: I don't have children of my own, but if I did, I think their daily routine would be pretty similar to what I experienced growing up. I imagine them waking up early, having a simple breakfast, and heading off to school. I'd want them to have a good education, so I'd make sure they had all the supplies they needed and encouraged them to read whenever they could. After school, I'd hope they'd have some time to unwind, maybe play outside or do homework, and then have a family dinner. I'd also want them to be involved in something they're passionate about—maybe a club or a sport. I know how important it is to have support and opportunities, and I'd do everything I could to give them that. But honestly, I think the most important thing would be for them to know they're loved and that they can always count on their family, no matter what.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood brought up a lot of mixed feelings. Talking about my parents and brother reminded me of how far we've all come, even if we don't always agree on everything. It's interesting how my brother managed to break the cycle we were in, and I feel proud of him for that. At the same time, I can't help but think about the parts of my family history that feel incomplete, like the relatives I never got to know. It's strange how much those missing pieces affect me, even if I don't resent them. Then there's my neighborhood—living here has been a comfort, but I also feel stuck in a way. I love the sense of community and the safety, but I know I could be doing more with my life if I had more opportunities. It's a balance between being content with what I have and wanting more, and I think that's something I'll have to keep working through.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Kristen Hansen: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky. I don't have any major chronic conditions, and I try to take care of myself as best as I can. I do have some mild back pain from years of sitting at a desk, especially with my job, but I manage it with regular stretching and occasional visits to the chiropractor. I also try to eat as healthily as possible, though it's not always easy on a tight budget. I make a point of eating plenty of vegetables and whole grains, and I try to limit processed foods. I used to be more active when I was younger, but as I've gotten older, I've found it harder to keep up with a regular exercise routine. I do walk a lot, especially around the neighborhood, and I try to go to the gym a couple of times a week when I can afford it. I also take my mom to her doctor appointments sometimes, and that keeps me more aware of the importance of regular check-ups. Overall, I feel pretty good, but I know that health is something I can't take for granted, especially with the stress that comes with work and life in general.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Kristen Hansen: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is the routine I've built over the years—like walking every evening and trying to eat well when I can. I also feel a sense of responsibility, especially since I take my mom to her doctor appointments. It reminds me that health is something we can't ignore, and I want to be around for my family as long as possible. But what makes it hard is the stress and the financial strain. Sometimes, I can't afford to go to the gym or buy fresh produce, and when I'm overwhelmed with work, I skip meals or forget to take care of myself. I know I should be more consistent, but it's not always easy when you're juggling so much. I guess I'm learning as I go, just like everyone else.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Kristen Hansen: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues, but there was a time when I struggled with some persistent fatigue and anxiety, especially after a particularly stressful period at work. I was handling a lot of cases at once, and it started to take a toll on me. I remember feeling like I was running on empty, and I wasn't sleeping well. I didn't want to burden anyone, so I tried to push through it, but eventually, I realized I needed to take a step back. I started seeing a therapist, which was something I hadn't done before. It was hard to open up at first, but it really helped me process some of the stress and emotions I'd been holding onto. I also made a conscious effort to prioritize rest and self-care more, even if it was just getting enough sleep or taking short breaks during the day. It wasn't easy, but it reminded me that taking care of my mental health is just as important as my physical health. I'm still working on it, but I feel more in control now than I did before.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Kristen Hansen: Honestly, I've had to make some adjustments in my work routine to manage the stress and fatigue I was dealing with. I started setting clearer boundaries, like taking short breaks throughout the day and not checking work emails after hours. It wasn't easy at first—especially since I feel responsible for my clients and want to be available for them. But I've come to realize that if I'm not taking care of myself, I can't take care of anyone else. I've also learned to ask for help when I need it, whether it's from my coworkers or my therapist. It's been a slow process, but I'm starting to feel more balanced. I don't want my health issues to define me, but I do think they've taught me the importance of self-compassion and knowing when to slow down. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Kristen Hansen: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I feel like I'm making progress in my life—taking those online courses, staying committed to my job, and taking better care of my mental health. It's been a long time since I felt like I was growing in a meaningful way, and that feels really good. On the other hand, there's still a lot of uncertainty. I worry about my financial future, about whether I'll ever be able to save enough to feel secure. I also worry about my parents as they get older. My dad has been having some trouble with his knees, and my mom is still working part-time, which I know isn't easy for her at her age. I want to help them, but I don't want to burden them with my own struggles. It's a lot to balance, but I think I'm learning how to do it. I've also been trying to reconnect with some old friends, like Sarah, and that's been a nice reminder of the support system I have. Life hasn't been perfect, but I feel like I'm on the right path, even if it's not always clear where it leads.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me reflect on how much I've been trying to grow, even in small ways. Taking those online courses has been a step toward feeling more in control of my future, and it's reminded me that learning doesn't stop when you're no longer in school. At the same time, talking about my health brought up the challenges of balancing work, family, and self-care. I've always tried to do what's right for everyone else, but I'm starting to realize that I need to prioritize myself more too. It's not always easy, especially with the financial strain and the stress of my job, but I'm trying. I think these conversations have helped me see that I'm not alone in feeling this way, and that's something I can hold onto as I keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Kristen Hansen: I think I've dealt with anxiety in different ways over the years, especially when things felt overwhelming. There were times when I would feel like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders—whether it was work, family, or just the uncertainty of the future. I used to try to push through it on my own, thinking that if I just worked harder or stayed busy, the feelings would go away. But I've come to realize that anxiety isn't something you can just power through. It's not a sign of weakness, and it doesn't mean I'm not strong. I've started to talk about it more, especially with my therapist, and that's been a huge relief. I still have days when I feel it creeping in, but I'm learning how to recognize the signs and take action before it gets too heavy. I think the biggest thing I've learned is that it's okay to not be okay, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not a failure.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Kristen Hansen: For my family, it's been a mix of things too. My parents are doing okay, but I can see the strain of aging on them. My dad's knees are getting worse, and he's been more careful about what he does around the house. My mom still works part-time, but she's starting to feel the physical toll of it, especially with the long hours. I worry about them, but I also know they're strong and have always been independent. My brother, Jake, has been a big support for both of them, even though he's living on the other side of the country. He checks in regularly, helps with errands when he can, and even video calls them every week. It's comforting to see him step up like that, especially since he's always been the more responsible one. I think my parents are proud of him, even if they don't always show it. As for me, I try to be there for them as much as I can, but I also have to balance my own life. It's not always easy, but I know they're important to me, and I want to make sure they're taken care of as they get older.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Kristen Hansen: For me, religion has always been a source of comfort and stability, especially during the harder times in my life. I was raised Catholic, and even though I don't go to church every single Sunday anymore, I still find meaning in the rituals and the sense of community that comes with it. My mom used to take me to Sunday Mass when I was a kid, and I remember how peaceful it felt to sit there, listening to the priest speak and watching the people around me. It wasn't just about faith for me—it was about belonging, about knowing that no matter what was going on in my life, there was a place where I could feel connected to something bigger. I think that's why I still go to church, even if it's not as often as I used to. It reminds me of where I came from, of the values I was taught, and of the people who have supported me along the way. I don't claim to have all the answers, and I know that faith looks different for everyone, but for me, it's been a quiet strength that I carry with me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Kristen Hansen: I don't use social media much, to be honest. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and a few old friends, but I don't post much or engage with the content very often. I think it's more of a passive thing for me—checking in occasionally to see what's going on with my brother or my parents, or to see if someone from my past has posted something. I've never really felt the need to share my life online, and I don't want to get caught up in the constant stream of updates and opinions. There's something about being offline that feels more real to me, like I can focus on the people and things that matter without the distraction. I know it's not for everyone, but for me, it's just not something I need in my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Kristen Hansen: Honestly, I don't think social media would be much help for me during tough times. I know people find support in online communities, but I've always been more of an in-person person. I trust the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, my coworkers—more than I trust what I see online. There's a lot of noise out there, and I don't want to get caught up in someone else's problems or feel like I have to put on a certain image. When I'm going through something hard, I'd rather talk to someone face-to-face, even if it's just my brother on the phone or my coworker Mark offering a listening ear. I think the real support comes from the people you already know and care about, not from strangers on the internet.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent experiences made me reflect on how much I've been trying to grow, even in small ways. Taking those online courses has been a step toward feeling more in control of my future, and it's reminded me that learning doesn't stop when you're no longer in school. At the same time, talking about my health brought up the challenges of balancing work, family, and self-care. I've always tried to do what's right for everyone else, but I'm starting to realize that I need to prioritize myself more too. It's not always easy, especially with the financial strain and the stress of my job, but I'm trying. I think these conversations have helped me see that I'm not alone in feeling this way, and that's something I can hold onto as I keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Kristen Hansen: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have gone up and down, depending on what's going on at work and with my family. There were times when I felt like I was handling everything pretty well—keeping up with my online courses, staying on top of my job responsibilities, and making sure my parents were okay. But then there were other times when I felt like I was barely keeping my head above water. I think the biggest change in my emotional coping strategies has been learning to ask for help more often. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I've realized that's not sustainable. I've started talking to my therapist more regularly, and I've also leaned on my friends and coworkers when I needed support. I've even started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and recognize that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. I think that's the biggest shift I've made—accepting that I don't have to be perfect, and that taking care of my mental health is just as important as anything else.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Kristen Hansen: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my car payment. Rent is the biggest chunk of my budget—about $800 a month for my apartment. I try to keep it simple, but with the cost of living here, it's still a lot. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to eat healthily, but sometimes I have to stretch my budget by buying in bulk or choosing cheaper options. My car payment is around $250, and I know that's something I could cut back on if I needed to, but I rely on it for getting to work and visiting my parents. I also have a few smaller expenses, like my phone bill, utilities, and the occasional trip to the chiropractor for my back. I don't have a lot left over after all that, so I'm always careful with my spending. I try to set aside a little bit each month for savings, but it's hard when the amount is so small. I know I could be doing better financially, but I'm trying to make the most of what I have and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Kristen Hansen: To be honest, my household spending last month was pretty much the same as usual—around $1,500 to $1,600. That includes rent, groceries, my car payment, and the basics like utilities and phone bills. I don't usually have a lot of extra money, so I have to be really careful with every dollar. Sometimes, if I get a little extra from overtime at work or a small bonus, I'll set that aside for savings, but it's usually just a few hundred dollars at most. I know I could be doing better financially, but I'm trying to make the most of what I have and keep moving forward. It's not always easy, especially with the cost of living here, but I'm learning to be more intentional with my spending and to prioritize what really matters.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Kristen Hansen: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment complex near the edge of Des Moines, which is more affordable than buying a house would be on my income. Renting gives me flexibility, especially since I'm not sure where life will take me in the next few years. I've considered buying a home someday, but with my current financial situation, it feels out of reach. I know that stability is important, and I hope one day I can save enough to make that dream a reality. For now, renting is just about surviving and staying in a place that feels safe and familiar.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Kristen Hansen: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the rest of my life. In the winter months, my utility bills go up because I use more electricity for heating, and that's something I have to watch closely. I also noticed that during the holidays, my grocery expenses went up a bit because I tend to buy more food for family gatherings or just feel like treating myself a little. But the biggest fluctuation was when my mom had to go to the doctor for a check-up—those medical bills can really add up, especially when insurance doesn't cover everything. I had to set aside some extra money for that, which meant cutting back on other things, like going out to eat or buying new clothes. Then there were the months when I had to pay for my online courses, which added a small but consistent expense to my budget. It's been a learning process, trying to balance these changes without letting them throw me off track. I've started tracking my spending more carefully, and it's helped me see where I can adjust to make things a little easier on myself.

Going through the interview questions about my family and my use of social media made me reflect on how much my relationships and personal habits shape my daily life. Talking about my parents and brother reminded me of the strength they've shown, even as they age and face their own challenges. It's comforting to know that my brother is there for them, even from afar, and that I try to be there for them too, even when my own life feels uncertain. At the same time, thinking about social media made me realize how little I rely on it. I've always preferred real, in-person connections over the noise and comparison of online platforms. It's a reminder that the people I already know and care about are the ones who truly matter, and that I don't need to be connected to the wider world through screens to feel supported. These conversations have helped me appreciate the balance I've found in my life—staying grounded in my family, my community, and my own values, even when things don't always go as planned.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Kristen Hansen: I don't save in the traditional sense, like having a big savings account or emergency fund. The truth is, I've never really had the luxury of saving much. My income is pretty tight, and after paying for rent, groceries, my car, and the occasional medical bill, there's not much left. I do try to set aside a little bit each month, maybe $50 or so, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not much, but it's something. I know I should be saving more, but it's hard when you're always trying to make ends meet. I've had to learn to be really careful with what little I have, and I try not to spend on things that aren't necessary. I guess I'm still figuring out how to balance saving with the day-to-day needs of my life. It's something I hope to get better at as I move forward, but for now, I'm just trying to stay afloat.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Kristen Hansen: In the last year, I've been trying to save for a rainy day, but it's been really challenging with the way my income is. I set a small goal of saving $100 a month, just to have something in case of an emergency, but honestly, most months I only manage to save a fraction of that. I know it's not much, but it's something. I also dream of one day being able to save enough for a down payment on a house, but that feels so far away right now. I think about it sometimes, especially when I see my neighbors buying homes or when I pass by a real estate sign. It's not that I don't want to own a place—it's just that I feel like I'm stuck in this cycle where I'm barely making it month to month. I hope that as I keep working, taking those online courses, and maybe even getting a promotion someday, I can start saving more. For now, I'm just trying to be realistic and not get too discouraged by how slow the progress is.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Kristen Hansen: My occupation is as a case manager at a local social services agency, and the work I do is both challenging and deeply meaningful. My main responsibilities involve supporting clients who are dealing with a wide range of issues—housing instability, domestic violence, mental health struggles, or just needing someone to talk to during a tough time. I spend a lot of time meeting with clients, either in person or over the phone, to assess their needs and connect them with the right resources. That could mean helping them find temporary housing, applying for government assistance, or just being there to listen when they don't know where else to turn. One of the most important parts of my job is building trust with the people I work with. It's not always easy—some clients are hesitant to open up, especially if they've been through a lot. But when they do, it's incredibly rewarding to see them take steps toward stability, even if it's just a small one. I also work closely with other professionals, like counselors, housing coordinators, and legal aid workers, to make sure clients get the full support they need. It's a lot to juggle, but I find purpose in knowing that I'm making a difference, even if it's one person at a time.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Kristen Hansen: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes feel like more when I'm juggling a lot of cases or dealing with unexpected issues. My job isn't just about the hours—it's about being available when someone needs me, even if that means staying late or coming in early. I've learned to be flexible, and while it can be exhausting, I know that the people I work with are counting on me. I try to keep a regular schedule, but there are days when I have to adjust. I think that's just part of the job—being there for others when they need it most, even if it means sacrificing a little of my own time.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Kristen Hansen: No, I haven't had more than one job. I've always focused on my full-time role at the social services agency because I believe in the work I do and the impact it has on people's lives. I know some people take on multiple jobs to make ends meet, and I admire their dedication and resilience. But for me, it's been about finding a balance between work, family, and my own well-being. I've considered part-time work in the past, maybe something flexible like tutoring or administrative support, but I've always felt that my current job, while demanding, is the most fulfilling for me. I don't want to spread myself too thin, especially with the responsibilities I have at home and the ongoing care of my parents. I think I've learned to be content with what I have, even if it's not perfect, and I'm trying to make the most of the opportunities I do have.

Going through the interview questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and my family and social media use made me reflect on how much I've been trying to grow, even in small ways. I've been learning to ask for help more often, whether it's from my therapist, my friends, or my coworkers, and that's been a big shift for me. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I'm starting to see that it's okay to lean on others. At the same time, talking about my family reminded me of how important they are to me, even when we don't always agree on everything. My brother's support for my parents, and my own efforts to be there for them, show how much we all rely on each other. And thinking about social media made me realize how little I need it in my life—I've always preferred real, in-person connections, and that's something I'm grateful for. These conversations have helped me appreciate the balance I've found in my life, even when things don't always go as planned.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Kristen Hansen: In terms of income, my household makes about $2,800 a month from my full-time job. That's not a lot, especially when you factor in the rising cost of living here in Des Moines. I don't have any other sources of income, so it's all on me to make sure we can cover the essentials. I know it's not enough to live comfortably, but it's enough to keep a roof over my head, put food on the table, and take care of my parents when they need help. I've had to make some tough choices over the years—like not going on vacation or skipping out on social events—to make sure I can keep up with my responsibilities. It's not always easy, but I've learned to be resourceful and to prioritize what truly matters. I hope that as I continue to grow in my career and finish those online courses, I can eventually earn more and have a little more financial security. For now, I'm just trying to do the best I can with what I have.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Kristen Hansen: I've been at my current job for about five years now, and while it's not always easy, I've grown a lot in that time. The benefits package is pretty standard for a public sector job—health insurance, dental, vision, and a modest retirement plan. I also get about 10 days of paid vacation a year, plus sick leave and some personal days. It's not the most generous package, but it's enough to cover the basics. I've been lucky to have a good relationship with my supervisor, who's always been supportive, even when I've had to take on more than my share. I think the biggest benefit of this job, though, is the sense of purpose it gives me. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I feel like I'm doing something that matters, and that's something I can't put a price on.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Kristen Hansen: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I have a decent rapport with my manager, who I've mentioned before—she's been supportive throughout the years, even when I've had to take on more than my share. She's not the type to micromanage, which I really appreciate, and she's always been willing to listen when I've had concerns or needed guidance. As for my coworkers, we get along well. We're all in the same boat, dealing with the same challenges, and there's a real sense of camaraderie. Mark, the coworker I mentioned earlier, is someone I really trust—when I'm feeling overwhelmed, he's always there to offer a listening ear or a bit of advice. We don't always agree on everything, but we respect each other's work and the fact that we're all trying to do our best. I think that's what makes the workplace feel like a team, even if it's not perfect. There are days when things get stressful or when I feel like I'm not making a difference, but knowing I have people I can rely on makes it easier to keep going.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Kristen Hansen: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are occasional fluctuations depending on the needs of the clients we serve. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and finish at 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up a case or meet with a client who can't make it during regular hours. My manager is pretty flexible, which is something I really appreciate, especially when I need to adjust my schedule for family reasons or when I'm juggling my online courses. That said, I do wish there were more opportunities for remote work or flexible hours, especially as I get older and start thinking more about my long-term health and well-being. For now, the predictability of the schedule is a good thing—it gives me a sense of structure, even when the work itself can be unpredictable. I know I can count on my coworkers to cover for me when I need to step away, and that kind of support makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Kristen Hansen: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a constant balancing act. It's not that I'm unhappy with what I have—it's just that I know there's more I could be doing, more I could be saving, more I could be earning. I've always been the type to look at the bigger picture, and I can't help but feel like I'm stuck in a place where I'm not really moving forward. I work hard, I try to be responsible, but I also know that my income isn't enough to give me the security I want for myself or for my parents as they get older. I worry about the future, about whether I'll ever be able to afford something more stable, or even just have a little more freedom in my life. But at the same time, I try not to dwell too much on what I don't have. I remind myself that I have a job that matters, that I have a family who supports me in their own way, and that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. It's not perfect, but I think that's just part of life for a lot of people in my situation. I'm still learning, still trying to figure out how to make things better, and I hope that one day, I'll look back and see that I made the right choices, even if they didn't feel like it at the time.

Going through the interview questions about my bills, savings, and work has made me reflect on how much of my life is about managing what little I have. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the constant uncertainty that comes with my income. Some months are tighter than others, and I have to be careful with every dollar I earn. It's not always easy, but I've learned to be resourceful and prioritize what truly matters. When it comes to saving, I know I could be doing better, but I'm trying to set aside even small amounts each month, just in case. It's not much, but it's something. And when it comes to my job, I feel a sense of purpose even if the pay isn't great. I know I'm making a difference in people's lives, even if it's one person at a time. I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm still trying to move forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Kristen Hansen: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were never the same as what I imagine people in more stable financial situations have. My mom worked part-time at the same local store she's still at today, and my dad worked in manufacturing, which was a steady job but not one that paid well. They both worked hard to make sure we had everything we needed, even if it wasn't much. I remember my dad coming home tired after long shifts, and my mom always trying to stretch the budget so we could afford groceries and bills. I think that's why I chose to go into social work—because I wanted to help people like them, who are working hard but still struggling to make ends meet. It's funny, though, because even though they worked, there were times when I felt like I was the one who had to step up and take care of things, especially after my parents divorced. I guess that's when I really started to understand the weight of responsibility, and how important it is to have a stable income and a sense of security.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Kristen Hansen: My mom worked part-time at a local grocery store, and my dad worked in manufacturing at a plant just outside of town. Their jobs were pretty straightforward—my mom's involved restocking shelves, checking out customers, and keeping the store running smoothly, while my dad's was more about assembling parts on the factory floor. Both of them had to be really careful with their time, especially since they were working multiple shifts or overtime when needed. I remember my dad coming home with calluses on his hands and my mom always having a tired look in her eyes, even after a short shift. They never complained, though—they just kept working, knowing that it was the only way to provide for us. I think that's why I always felt like I had to be responsible, even as a kid. I saw how hard they worked, and I wanted to make sure I didn't end up in the same situation they were in. It's funny, looking back, because I didn't realize at the time that their work was just as meaningful as anything else—just different. They gave me a foundation, even if it wasn't always easy.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Kristen Hansen: My mom worked at a local grocery store called 'Hansen's Market,' which has been around for decades. It's one of those old-fashioned places where the same families have shopped for generations. She was a cashier and also helped with restocking shelves when needed. The store wasn't huge, but it was a staple in our neighborhood, and my mom took pride in knowing the regular customers by name. My dad worked at a manufacturing plant called 'Des Moines Fabrications,' which made parts for construction equipment. It was a union job, which gave him some stability, but the pay wasn't great, and the work was physically demanding. He spent most of his day on the factory floor, assembling metal components. I remember him coming home with sore muscles and a sense of pride, even if he didn't make a lot of money. Both of them worked hard, and I think that's why I grew up with such a strong work ethic. I always felt like I had to do better, not just for myself, but for them too.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Kristen Hansen: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, even if I'm not where I want to be financially. I hope I've finished those online courses and maybe even have a promotion or a chance to take on more responsibility at the agency. I want to feel like I'm making a real difference in people's lives, not just going through the motions. I also hope my parents are still healthy and that my brother is doing well—maybe even that he's back here for a visit or that we can all get together more often. I don't know if I'll ever be able to afford a house or have a lot of savings, but I hope I'm not stuck in the same cycle my parents were in. I want to be more secure, more in control of my future, and more present for the people I care about. I guess I just hope that, no matter what happens, I'm still growing, still learning, and still trying to be the best version of myself.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Kristen Hansen: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have been there for me through thick and thin. My family, even with all our differences, has always been my foundation. I value the relationships I've built, like the one with Sarah, who's been a constant in my life, or with Mark at work, who's always got my back. I also value the small things that bring me peace, like the quiet of my neighborhood, the library where I feel at home, or the simple act of reading a good book. I value the work I do, even if it's not perfect, because it gives me a sense of purpose. And I value the lessons I've learned along the way—about resilience, about asking for help, and about finding strength in the little things. I think what I value most is the ability to keep going, even when life feels heavy, because I know that as long as I have those people, those moments, and that sense of purpose, I'm not alone.

Going through the interview questions about my work, relationships at work, and the predictability of my schedule made me reflect on how much my job shapes my daily life. It's not always easy, but I find purpose in the work I do, even if the pay isn't great. I value the relationships I've built with my coworkers and manager—they make the long hours and stress more bearable. I also appreciate the predictability of my schedule, even though there are occasional fluctuations. It gives me a sense of structure, which is important when life feels so uncertain in other areas. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm trying to make the most of what I have, and I'm grateful for the people who support me along the way.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been both a journey of remembrance and a moment of clarity. It's strange how revisiting the details of my life—my childhood, my choices, my struggles, and my small victories—has brought so much into focus. I've always known that I came from a working-class family, that I made the conscious decision to pursue education over immediate stability, and that I've spent most of my life helping others through my work in social services. But putting it all together like this has made me realize how deeply interconnected everything is. My parents' sacrifices, the support I received from teachers and mentors like Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Delgado, the relationships I've built with my brother, my coworkers, and my friends—all of it has shaped who I am today. I've always felt like I was walking a tightrope between responsibility and self-care, between wanting to do more for my family and wanting to build a better life for myself. But now, looking back, I see that I've made it this far, and that in itself is a kind of victory. I may not have everything I want, but I have a purpose, a sense of community, and a family that, despite our differences, has always been there for me. This interview has reminded me that my story is not just about the struggles I've faced, but also about the strength I've found in the people and moments that have carried me through. I'm not done growing, and I know there's still more to learn, but I feel more grounded in who I am than I have in a long time.
